article:
One of my patients was an old lady, who had only a few months to live.   _  ,
she had never been given a birthday party before. I wanted her to  _  the feeling of a celebration in her honor and  _  her that I would give her a perfect party.
  _   the party brought her great joy. One particular   _  involved a trip to
bakery famous for its fine pastries .   _  the woman had heard of
this  _  , she'd never gone inside to try its
goods because she could not  _  them. When I
suggested that we go to the bakery to  _  the
pastries for her party, she got out of her  _  and
walked unaided to the door. It was the first time I'd ever seen her walk  _  . When we got to the bakery, she walked in and  _  to
the clerk, "We're having a party!" Although she was too  _  to do much more than eat the sweets by taking very small bites, she
didn't stop  looking around  in total wonderment; no detail of
the shop escaped her notice.
On the day of the party, she got up   _  and dressed herself in her best suit. Even
though there were holes in her suit, she was proud to  _  it.
By 7:00 a.m. she positioned herself in her wheelchair and became Queen for the Day.
  _   a week after the party, this woman who never smiled, because her   _  life
had given her little to smile about, smiled widely. "I guess we can  _  ourselves for the party we had!" she said. Her joy was the direct
result of fulfilling  the very real human need to feel  _  . She died a few weeks
later.
